messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

> Maybe, but how many people will already have been discouraged from using
> your library just because you didn't give them enough hooks?

In my experience? None. Zip Zero. Zilch. Not even once.

I have seen many, many developers discouraged from using libraries that
were too complex and confusing. Size of the public API is part of that
complexity.

> Actually, most of the time, it is. I mentioned MIDP1 above, but even if you
> are thinking of open-source libraries, modifying the source means forking
> the code most of the time, with all the maintenance nightmare that ensue.

But possible, which is why open source libraries are preferable.

> You seem to be living in a world where every author of any imaginable
> library is magically available and willing to make the changes you need when
> you ask for them right away.

In general, they are, provided you're willing to pay a market rate for
their time. Of course, if you want people to do things for free, then
you might have to wait a little longer (or not. Depends on the project.)

One of the principles of JUnit is to do the simplest thing that could
possibly work. That principle goes deeper than test-driven development
though. It applies in a lot of areas including API design. You're
advocating big upfront design, which I thought was an idea we had laid
to rest, at least in this group. Designing an API in advance of the uses
to which the API will be put is not only more work. It's also going to
produce a worse API because whatever you do design won't fit the use
cases. It's only when you have a clear picture of what the users
actually need to do that you can create the right API to fit the problem.
